contentrichtext.text: '''Object Lisp''' was a [[computer]] [[programming language]], a dialect of the [[Lisp (programming language)|Lisp]] language. It was an [[object-oriented programming|object-oriented]] extension for the Lisp dialect [[Lisp Machine Lisp]], designed by [[Lisp Machines]], Inc. Object Lisp was also an early example of [[prototype-based programming]]. It was seen as a competitor to other object-oriented extensions to Lisp at around the same time such as [[Flavors (programming language)|Flavors]], in use by [[Symbolics]], [[Common Objects]] developed by [[Hewlett-Packard]], and [[CommonLoops]], in use by [[Xerox]]. Object Lisp was also used in early versions of [[Macintosh Common Lisp]]. There, the user interface toolkit was written using Object Lisp. ==References== [http://groups.google.com/groups?selm=13400015%40ccvaxa 14 December 1985 net.lang.lisp USENET post about the Common Lisp meeting in Boston, 9-11 December 1985, which discusses Object Lisp] [http://lispm.dyndns.org/documentation/ObjectLisp-Manual.pdf "ObjectLISP User Manual", G. Drescher, LMI 1985] {{FOLDOC}} [[Category:Object-oriented programming languages]] [[Category:Lisp programming language family]] {{prog-lang-stub}}
